{{Speciesbox |image = Agave eggersiana.jpg |taxon = Agave eggersiana |authority = Trel. }}
'''''Agave eggersiana''''' is an [[endangered species]] of spiky [[plant]] which grows in the [[Virgin Islands]], in dry, exposed areas. ''Agave eggersiana'' is a perennial herb known only from the island of St. Croix of the U.S. Virgin Islands (USFWS 1998a). It is known from a small number of wild and cultivated plants (USFWS 1998a). It is being cultivated at the St. George Village Botanical Garden in St. Croix U.S.V.I.(USFWS 1998a) and at Fairchild Botanical Garden in south Florida.
This species can grow up to seven meters in height and has large, yellow tubular flowers that produce flattened black seeds (USFWS 1998a). A small number of plants remain on private land and are threatened by tourist development (USFWS 1998b). The greatest threat is habitat destruction brought on by residential development on private land. Other threats include feral pigs and goats on National Park Service land (USFWS 1998b). Research needs include distribution and abundance, general biology and ecology (USFWS 1998a). The U.S. Fish and Wildlife requests that any interested parties (concerned government agencies, the scientific community and/or industry) submit data or suggestions concerning this species (USFWS 1998b).
==References== *USFWS. 1998 November 17, 1998. News Release: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Determines two Virgin Island plants may warrant listing under Endangered Species Act. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service *http://www.virginislandsdailynews.com/index.pl/article?id=17628587
*USFWS. Endangered and threatened wildlife and plants, initiation of status review for Agave eggersiana and Solanum conocarpum: Initiation of status review and solicitation of new Information, published Jan. 20, 2010, information by Feb. 19, 2010 *http://edocket.access.gpo.gov/2010/2010-870.htm
[[Category:Agave|eggersiana]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox software | name = Quanta Plus | screenshot = [[Image:QuantaPlus.png|250px]] | caption = Quanta Plus 3.3.0 | developer = The Quanta Team | latest release version = 3.5.9 | latest release date = {{release date|2008|02|20}} | operating system = [[Unix-like]] | genre = [[HTML editor]] | license = [[GNU General Public License|GPL]] | website = http://quanta.kdewebdev.org }} '''Quanta Plus''', originally called '''Quanta''', is a [[World Wide Web|web]] [[Integrated development environment]] (IDE) for [[HTML]], [[XHTML]], [[Cascading Style Sheets|CSS]], [[XML]], [[PHP]] and any other XML-based languages or scripting languages. It is part of [[KDE]], a [[Linux]] desktop environment, released in the [[Kdewebdev]] package. Quanta was licensed under GPL before the release of version 2.0 final.
Quanta is capable of both [[WYSIWYG]] design and handcoding. It features tag completion on the fly, tag editing through a dialog interface, script language variable auto-completion, project management, live preview, PHP debugger, [[Concurrent Versions System|CVS]] support, [[Subversion (software)|Subversion]] support (through external plugin). The other Kdewebdev applications, [[Kommander]], [[KImageMapEditor]], [[KXSLDbg]], [[KLinkStatus]], [[KFileReplace]], are tightly integrated with Quanta, but can be used independently as well.
==Features== *'''Project management''', including support for local and remote (through the network) projects. Project files can be uploaded to many servers using various protocols. CVS support is integrated, Subversion support is possible through external plugins. Advanced project features, like actions assigned to various project events and assigning roles in a team are also available. *Uses KDE [[KIO|KIO slaves]] for [[FTP]], [[Secure Shell|SSH]] (through [[Files transferrer over shell protocol|FISH]]) and other protocol support. *'''HTML and XML support''': by default support for various (X)HTML versions and some XML based languages are available. This support can be extended either by the user (by importing an XML [[Document Type Definition|DTD]]) or via the "hotstuff" interface, by downloading XML support packages. XML support means autocompletion of tags and attributes, visual editing of tags, document structure viewing, validation/problem reporting, context help. *'''script language support''': by default '''PHP''' support is included, other languages can be supported by creating a language description package. PHP debugger interface is included for the Gubed and XDebug debuggers. Autocompletion for built in and user functions/variables is possible. *'''CSS support''': visual CSS editor, autocompletion for CSS. *'''templates''': full site, one document or snippet templates are possible. Templates can be shared via hotstuff. *'''user toolbars and actions''': toolbars can be freely created with stock or actions created by the user on it. The toolbars can be assigned to a language or to a project. The toolbars are also shareable via hotstuff. *'''extensibility''': any type of scripts/executables can be assigned to actions or project events. Users can exchange toolbars through the hotstuff system. *'''plugins''': general [[KPart]] plugin support. Any KDE KPart can be used inside Quanta, by default [[Konsole]], KImageMapEditor, KLinkStatus, [[Cervisia]] (CVS) and KFileReplace are configured. *'''integrated preview''': documents can be previewed inside the application using the KHTML engine. Preprocessing the documents through a web server before previewing is possible. *'''context help''': context help for many languages can be downloaded via hotstuff. New help packages can be created by the user. *'''lots of settings''': the application is highly configurable, so everyone can adapt it to their needs. *Built in rendering with [[KHTML]]. *Display the source code, WYSIWYG Mode (called VPL (Visual Page Layout) in Quanta) or both.
== See also == {{Portal|Free software}} * [[List of HTML editors]] * [[Comparison of HTML editors]]
== Further reading == *The People Behind Quanta Plus: [http://www.kde.de/appmonth/2003/quanta/interview.php German], [http://web.archive.org/web/20071221021554/http://dot.kde.org/1050969840/ English (translated)] *[http://www.linux.com/articles/27249 Review of Quanta+ and Quanta Gold] *[http://web.archive.org/web/20050413012755/http://www.techdigest.org/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=384&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0 Interview with Quanta: Eric Laffoon] *[http://www.osdir.com/Article5016.phtml OSDir.com Project of the Week: Quanta+] *[http://quanta.sourceforge.net/release2.php Quanta 2.0 Press Release] contains info on Quanta Gold
==External links== *[http://www.kde-apps.org/content/show.php?content=10135 KDE-Apps.org: Quanta Plus] *{{Freshmeat|quantaplus|Quanta Plus}}
{{HTML editors}} {{KDE}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Saroos | image = | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] | genre = [[Post-rock]], [[electronica]] | years_active = 2006–present | label = [[Anticon]], Alien Transistor | associated_acts = [[Odd Nosdam]] | website = {{URL|saroos.bandcamp.com}} | current_members = Florian Zimmer
Christoph Brandner
Max Punktezahl | past_members = }} '''Saroos''' is a [[post-rock]] trio from [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]. It consists of Florian Zimmer, Christoph Brandner and Max Punktezahl.{{cite web|url=http://fluctuat.premiere.fr/Musique/News/Saroos-La-mecanique-des-fluides-3195484|title=Saroos : La mécanique des fluides|publisher=''Premiere''|first=Maxence|last=Grugier|date=06/12/2006}} ==History== Saroos released the self-titled debut album, ''Saroos'', on Alien Transistor in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.textura.org/archives/s/saroos.htm|title=Saroos: Saroos|publisher=''textura''|date=November 2006}} The second album, ''[[See Me Not]]'', was released on [[Anticon]] in the United States and on Alien Transistor elsewhere in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.electronicbeats.net/features/news/saroos-release-see-me-not|title=Saroos release See Me Not|publisher=''Electronic Beats''|first=Ari|last=Stein|date=October 20, 2010}} It was produced by [[Odd Nosdam]].{{cite web|url=http://badpandarecords.wordpress.com/2012/03/19/badpanda119/|title=LIFE & LIMB with Saroos – Mirrored Selves|publisher=''Bad Panda Records''|date=19 March 2012}} The band toured Europe in promotion of the album.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalinberlin.de/saroos-berlin/|title=Saroos & Odd Nosdam @ NBI Berlin | Sunday, 05.12.2010|publisher=''Digital In Berlin''|date=November 30, 2010}} Saroos released the single "Yukoma (Populous Remix)" b/w "Outrigger (feat. [[Jel]])" on Alien Transistor in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.xlr8r.com/mp3/2011/01/yukoma-populous-remix|title=Saroos "Yukoma (Populous Remix)"|publisher=''XLR8R''|first=Patric|last=Farron|date=January 5, 2011}} The band also toured Europe with [[13 & God]] in the same year.{{cite web|url=http://plemplemkaufraum.wordpress.com/2011/05/16/13-god-new-album-tour/|title=13 & God – new album – tour|publisher=''PlemPlem|date=May 16, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dmute.net/reportage-concert-80_-_13-+-God-+-Saroos-@-Maroquinerie-(21-05-2011).html|title=13 & God + Saroos @ Maroquinerie (21/05/2011)|publisher=''dMute.net''|author=Mathias|date=23 May, 2011}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''Saroos'' (2006) * ''[[See Me Not]]'' (2010) ===Singles=== * "Yukoma (Populous Remix)" b/w "Outrigger (feat. [[Jel]])" (2011) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official|saroos.bandcamp.com}} * [http://www.alientransistor.de/index.php?level=2&CatID=101.132&inhalt_id=130 Saroos] on Alien Transistor {{Anticon}} [[Category:Anticon]] [[Category:German post-rock groups]]

{{Taxobox | image = Pulveroboletus ravenelii 58493.jpg | image_width = 240px | image_caption = ''Pulveroboletus ravenelii'' | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Boletales]] | familia = [[Boletaceae]] | genus = '''''Pulveroboletus''''' | genus_authority = [[William Murrill|Murrill]] (1909) | type_species = ''Pulveroboletus ravenelii'' | type_species_authority = ([[Miles Joseph Berkeley|Berk.]] & [[Moses Ashley Curtis|M.A.Curtis]]) [[William Alphonso Murrill|Murrill]] (1909) | subdivision_ranks = Species | subdivisions = }} '''''Pulveroboletus''''' is a [[genus]] of fungi in the [[Boletaceae]] family. The genus has a [[cosmopolitan distribution]] and contains 25 species.<ref name=Kirk2008/>
==Taxonomy== The genus was first described by American mycologist [[William Alphonso Murrill]] in 1909. He defined species in the genus as having a cap and stem "clothed with a conspicuous sulphur-yellow, powdery tomentum, which may be the remains of a universal veil: context white, fleshy; tubes adnate, yellowish, covered with a large veil: spores oblong-ellipsoid, ochraceous-brown: stipe solid, annulate, not reticulate." Murrill set ''Pulveroboletus ravenelii'' as the [[type species]]''.<ref name=Murrill1909/>
==Species== *''[[Pulveroboletus aberrans]]''<ref name=Heinemann1951/> *''[[Pulveroboletus acaulis]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus annulatus]]''<ref name=Heinemann1951/> *''[[Pulveroboletus auriflammeus]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus bembae]]''<ref name=Degreef2009/> *''[[Pulveroboletus brunneoscabrosus]]''<ref name=Takahashi2007/> *''[[Pulveroboletus carminiporus]]''<ref name=Heinemann1951/> *''[[Pulveroboletus cavipes]]''<ref name=Heinemann1951/> *''[[Pulveroboletus croceus]]''<ref name=Heinemann1951/> *''[[Pulveroboletus flaviporus]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus frians]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus icterinus]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus innixus]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus luteocarneus]]''<ref name=Degreef2009/> *''[[Pulveroboletus melleoluteus]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus parvulus]]''<ref name=Natarajan2009/> *''[[Pulveroboletus paspali]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus phaeocephalus]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus ravenelii]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus reticulopileus]]''<ref name=Zang2001/> *''[[Pulveroboletus ridleyi]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus rolfeanus]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus rosaemariae]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus trinitensis]]''<ref name=Heinemann1954/> *''[[Pulveroboletus viridis]]''<ref name=Heinemann1951/> *''[[Pulveroboletus viridisquamosus]]'' *''[[Pulveroboletus xylophilus]]''
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em|refs=
<ref name=Degreef2009>{{cite journal |author=Degreef J, De Kesel A. |year=2009 |title=Two new African ''Pulveroboletus'' with ornamented spores |journal=Mycotaxon |volume=108 |issue= |pages=54–65}}</ref>
<ref name=Heinemann1951>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3666673 |author=Heinemann P. |year=1951 |title=Champignons récoltés au Congo Belge par Madame Goossens-Fontana 1. ''Boletineae'' |journal=Bulletin du Jardin botanique de l'État a Bruxelles |volume=21 |issue=3/4 |pages=223–346 |jstor=3666673 }}</ref>
<ref name=Heinemann1954>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3666866 |author=Heinemann P. |year=1954 |title=Un bolet de l'ile de la Trinite |journal=Bulletin du Jardin botanique de l'État a Bruxelles |volume=24 |issue=2 |pages=121–25 |jstor=3666866 }}</ref>
<ref name=Kirk2008>{{cite book |author=Kirk PM, Cannon PF, Minter DW, Stalpers JA. |title=Dictionary of the Fungi |edition=10th |publisher=CABI |location=Wallingford |year=2008|page=581|isbn=978-0-85199-826-8}}</ref>
<ref name=Murrill1909>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3753167 |author=Murrill WA. |year=1909 |title=The Boletaceae of North America: I |journal=Mycologia |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=4–18 |jstor= 3753167 }}</ref>
<ref name=Natarajan2009>{{cite journal |author=Natarajan K, Purushothama KB. |year=2009 |title=''Pulveroboletus parvulus'' sp.nov. from South India |journal=Transactions of the British Mycological Society |volume=90 |issue=1 |pages=144–46 |doi=10.1016/S0007-1536(88)80198-0}}</ref>
<ref name=Takahashi2007>{{cite journal |author=Takahashi H. |title=Five new species of the Boletaceae from Japan |journal=Mycoscience |year=2007 |volume=48 |issue=2 |pages=90–9 |doi=10.1007/s10267-006-0332-6p}}</ref>
<ref name=Zang2001>{{cite journal |author=Zang M, Li T-H, Petersen RH. |year=2001 |title=Five new species of Boletaceae from China |journal=Mycotaxon |volume=80 |pages=481–87}}</ref>
}}

[[Image:Bonne - Carte hydro-geo-graphique des Indes Orientales.jpg|right|thumb|''Carte hydro-geo-graphique des Indes Orientales en deca et au dela du Gange avec leur archipel'', Paris 1771]] '''Rigobert Bonne''' (1727–1795) was one of the most important [[cartographer]]s of the late 18th century.
In 1773 Bonne succeeded Jacques Nicolas Bellin as Royal Cartographer to France in the office of the Hydrographer at the Depôt de la Marine. Working in his official capacity, Bonne compiled some of the most detailed and accurate maps of the period. Bonne’s work represents an important step in the evolution of the cartographic ideology away from the decorative work of the 17th and early 18th century towards a more detail oriented and practical aesthetic. With regard to the rendering of terrain Bonne maps bear many stylistic similarities to those of his predecessor, Bellin. However, Bonne maps generally abandon such common 18th century decorative features such as hand coloring, elaborate decorative [[cartouche]]s, and [[compass rose]]s.
While mostly focusing on coastal regions, the work of Bonne is highly regarded for its detail, historical importance, and overall aesthetic appeal.
==Principal Works==
* Maps for Guillaume Raynal's ''Atlas de toutes les parties connues du Globe Terrestre '' (Geneva, 1780) * Maps for ''Atlas Encyclopedique ... '' (2 volumes, Paris, 1788)
==References== {{commonscat|Rigobert Bonne}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.mostlymaps.com/reference/Map-Makers/rigobert-bonne.php |title=Rigobert Bonne (1729 - 1795) |accessdate=2007-09-25 |publisher=Mostlymaps}}

{{distinguish|Joshua James}} {{Infobox person |name = Josh James |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Josh James |birth_date = 1973 |birth_place = |residence = Alpine, Utah |alma_mater = [[Brigham Young University]] (dropout) |years_active = 1996–present |occupation = [[Domo (company)|Domo]] founder and CEO |known_for = [[Domo (company)|Domo]] founder and CEO
[[Omniture]] co-founder and CEO |networth = $100,000,000{{cite web|title=Omniture: A Radar Screen For E-biz|url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2007-04-29/omniture-a-radar-screen-for-e-biz|accessdate=1 December 2012}} |nationality = [[Americans|American]] |ethnicity = White |religion = [[Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints]] |spouse = Cherie James |relatives = |awards = Mountain West Capital Network Entrepreneur of the Year,2012
Enrst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year,2006
BYU Technology Entrepreneur of the Decade
Utah Technology Hall of Fame,2012 |website = {{URL|http://www.joshjames.com}} }} '''Josh James''' is an [[United States|American]] [[entrepreneur]] and founder and CEO of [[Domo (company)|Domo]] (formerly Cordahttp://venturebeat.com/2011/07/13/omniture-cofounder-domo-launch/), a software-as-a-service (SaaS) company he started in 2010 to fix the fundamental problems he saw in the business intelligence market. He raised $63 million http://techcrunch.com/2012/01/31/omniture-co-founders-business-intelligence-saas-company-domo-lands-20m-from-ivp/ in Series A funding from Benchmark Capital, IVP and a number of other high-profile Silicon Valley venture capital firms and angel investors.{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/14/domo-idUSN1E76C0ZT20110714 | work=Reuters | first=Sarah | last=McBride | title=Omniture founder obtains $33 mln for start-up | date=2011-07-14}} He also is the founder of CEO.com, an online resource for CEO-related news and information. Prior, James co-founded and served as [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Omniture]], a web analytics company. On his 33rd birthday, James rang the bell of the NYSE as Omniture went public in 2006{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/10/23/technology/omniture_josh_james.fortune | work=Fortune Magazine | first=Jessi | last=Hempel | title=Josh James: The man who measures the Web | date=2009-09-26}} and later sold the company to [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]] in 2009 for [[United States dollar|USD]] $1.8 billion. From 2006 to 2009, the three years that Omniture was public, James was the youngest CEO of a Nasdaq or New York Stock Exchange-traded company.{{cite news| url=http://www.forbes.com/2010/10/22/omniture-james-facebook-intelligent-investing-google.html | work=Forbes | first=Alexandra | last=Zendrian | title=Get Briefed: Josh James | date=2010-10-25}} Omniture was one of the top performing IPOs in 2006 and the number one returning venture investment out of 1,008 venture capital investments in 2004.{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/05/16/news/companies/onlineads_measurement/index.htm | work=CNN | first=Paul R. | last=La Monica | title=The other online ad boom | date=2007-05-16}} James served as Senior Vice President and General Manager of the Omniture Business Unit at Adobe until July 2010. In 2012, Mountain West Capital Network named James its Entrepreneur of the Year.http://www.mwcn.org/entrepreneur-of-the-year On June 27, 2012, James and Domo, Inc. received the ''Utah Valley Business Q'' "2012 UV50 TOP 10 Startups To Watch" award.http://utahvalleybusinessq.com/uv50/2012-uv50-top-10-startups-to-watch/ James was featured as #26 on [[40 under 40 (Fortune Magazine)|Fortune 40 under 40]] in 2009 and #1 on Fortune 40 under 40 "Ones to Watch" in 2011.{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/galleries/2011/news/companies/1110/gallery.40_under_40_ones_to_watch.fortune/index.html | work=CNN | title=40 Under 40: Ones to watch}}{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/10/23/technology/omniture_josh_james.fortune/index.htm?postversion=2009102609|title=Josh James: The man who measures the Web|publisher=Fortune|accessdate=2009-12-16 | date=2009-10-23 | first=Jessi | last=Hempel}}{{cite web|url=http://www.adobe.com/aboutadobe/pressroom/executivebios/|title=Adobe Executive Profiles|publisher=Adobe Systems|accessdate=2009-12-16}} He received the 2006 Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award and was named Technology Entrepreneur of the Decade by Brigham Young University. He was also recognized as Mountain West Capital's 2012 Entrepreneur of the Year. On November 30, 2012, James was inducted into the Utah Technology Hall of Fame along with Fred Lampropoulous, founder of [[Merit Medical Systems]].{{cite web|last=Harvey|first=Tom|title=Utah Tech Hall of Fame adding Lampropoulous, James|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/money/55356679-79/james-lampropoulous-utah-company.html.csp?page=1|publisher=Salt Lake Tribune|accessdate=1 December 2012}} James maintains a list of entrepreneurial advice for startup companies.http://www.joshjames.com/category/my-startup-rules/ He serves as a Young Global Leader with the World Economic Forum.http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/money/53659175-79/leaders-james-global-ceo.html.csp He also serves on the boards of Demand Media, a NYSE-traded company; Rakuten, a publicly traded, five billion dollar revenue company that is one of largest e-commerce companies in Japan; and Save the Children, the leading independent organization creating lasting change in the lives of children in need in the United States and around the world. Before co-founding Omniture James co-founded an interactive agency and two other businesses, which were subsequently sold to WebMediaBrands (formerly known as Jupitermedia) and Verisign. James founded Silicon Slopes, a private-sector initiative that promotes the interests of the high-tech industry in Utah. He attended Brigham Young University into his senior year but did not graduate. James is the oldest of six children. His father was an airline pilot and colonel in the Marines. He moved 17 times growing up. James served a two-year mission in Tokyo for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. He had roles as a child actor, which included appearing in episodes of Touched by an Angel and in a Kellogg's Honey Smacks commercial.http://www.inc.com/magazine/20100301/how-i-did-it-omnitures-josh-james.htmlhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BpjbKUEXyGchttp://www.joshjames.com/2012/04/dont-spend-money/ He is the brother of [[Zach James]], co-founder of MovieClips {{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5B20FF20091203|title=Web site puts film clips on tap|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2009-12-17 | date=2009-12-03}} ==External links== *[http://joshjames.com// JoshJames.com] *[http://omniture.com// Omniture.com] *[http://www.domo.com// Domo.com] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Persondata | NAME = James, Josh | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Entrepreneur, Co-founder of [[Omniture]], CEO of [[Domo (company)|Domo]] | DATE OF BIRTH = 1973 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:James, Josh}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:1973 births]] {{US-business-bio-stub}}

tags--> |elevation_m = 835 |elevation_ft = |postal_code_type = |postal_code = |area_code = |blank_name = [[List of Alberta provincial highways|Highways]] |blank_info = [[Alberta Highway 3|Highway 3]] |blank1_name = |blank1_info = |website = |footnotes = }} <!-- Infobox ends -->
'''Barnwell''' is a village in [[southern Alberta]], [[Canada]]. It is located {{convert|10|km|mi|abbr=on}} west of [[Taber, Alberta (town)|Taber]] and {{convert|43|km|mi|abbr=on}} east of [[Lethbridge]] along the [[Crowsnest Highway]], in the [[Taber, Alberta (municipal district)|Municipal District of Taber]].
== History == In the late 19th century, a [[boxcar]] was located on a [[rail siding]] in what is now Barnwell. It was used as a telegraph office for local settlers and the railroad, and the area was named Woodpecker. In 1908, the area was renamed Bountiful to correspond to the local school district. A short while later, it was renamed to Barnwell because another community already had the name of Bountiful. The name Barnwell came from William Barnwell, a longtime employee of the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}
Many of the early settlers of the area were coal miners employed in mines nearby at the former community of Coal City. The mines closed in 1920, and miners left for the [[Crowsnest Pass, Alberta|Crowsnest Pass]] and [[Drumheller, Alberta|Drumheller]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}
== Demographics == In the [[Canada 2011 Census|2011 Census]], the Village of Barnwell had a population of 771 living in 213 of its 217 total dwellings, a 24.8% change from its 2006 adjusted population of 618. With a land area of {{convert|1.49|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}, it had a population density of {{Pop density|771|1.49|km2|sqmi}} in 2011.<ref name=2011censusABmunis>{{cite web | url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2011/dp-pd/hlt-fst/pd-pl/Table-Tableau.cfm?LANG=Eng&T=302&SR=1&S=51&O=A&RPP=9999&PR=48&CMA=0 | title=Population and dwelling counts, for Canada, provinces and territories, and census subdivisions (municipalities), 2011 and 2006 censuses (Alberta) | publisher=Statistics Canada | date=2012-02-08 | accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
The population of the Village of Barnwell according to its 2011 municipal census is 812,<ref name=2011pop>{{cite web | url=http://www.municipalaffairs.alberta.ca/documents/msb/2011_pop.pdf | title=2011 Municipal Affairs Population List | publisher=Alberta Municipal Affairs | date=2010-10-05 | accessdate=2011-12-12}}</ref> a 32.5% increase from its 2006 federal census population of 613.<ref name=statcan2006/>
In 2006, Barnwell had a population of 613 living in 182 [[house|dwellings]], an 11.9% increase from 2001. The village has an area of {{convert|0.90|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and a [[population density]] of {{convert|680.5|/km2|/sqmi|abbr=on}}.<ref name=statcan2006>{{Cite web| url= http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/profiles/community/Details/Page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CSD&Code1=4802023&Geo2=PR&Code2=48&Data=Count&SearchText=Barnwell&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&B1=All&GeoLevel=&GeoCode=4802023 | title= Barnwell - Community Statistics | author= Statistics Canada| authorlink= Statistics Canada| year= [[Canada 2006 Census|Census 2006]] | accessdate= 2007-06-05}}</ref>
== Amenities == Barnwell is a small community, but it has several attractions. There is a seniors centre, a skate park, a K-9 school, a public library, three parks and a church. Fewer than 5 businesses operate in Barnwell.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}}
== See also == *[[List of communities in Alberta]] *[[List of villages in Alberta]]

page.title: Children of the Corn II: The Final Sacrifice

revision.comment: [[User:Addbot|Bot:]] Migrating 8 interwiki links, now provided by [[Wikipedia:Wikidata|Wikidata]] on [[d:q467947]] ([[User talk:Addbot|Report Errors]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox Film | name = Children of the Corn: The Final Sacrifice | image = ChildrenoftheCorn2.jpg | image_size = 190px | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[David Price (director)|David Price]] | producer = [[Scott A. Stone]]
[[David G. Stanley]] | starring = [[Terence Knox]]
Paul Scherrer
[[Ryan Bollman]]
[[Ned Romero]] | music = [[Daniel Licht]] | cinematography = Levie Isaacks | editing = Barry Zetlin | distributor = [[Dimension Films]]
[[Paramount Pictures]]
[[Anchor Bay Entertainment]] (UK rights) | released = January 29, 1993 (USA) | runtime = 94 min. | language = English | country = United States | budget = $900,000{{cite web |url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106557/business |title=IMDB Business and Box Office |accessdate=2007-12-28 |format= |work= }} | gross = $6,980,986 (USA) }} '''''Children of the Corn II: The Final Sacrifice''''' is the sequel to the 1984 movie ''[[Children of the Corn (film)|Children of the Corn]]''. This sequel, directed by David F. Price, stars Terence Knox, Ryan Bollman, Ned Romero, and Paul Scherrer. The film was released in theatres by [[Dimension Films]] in January 1993, with the video release handled by [[Paramount Pictures]]. Several sequels followed this movie, all but one of which were released directly to video.[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106557/movieconnections Movie links for Children of the Corn II: The Final Sacrifice (1993)] ==Plot== The plot involves [[Hemingford, Nebraska]], a town near Gatlin (the original film's setting). The people of Hemingford decide to adopt the surviving sadistic, savages of children in Gatlin, intending to help the children start new lives. Unfortunately for the well-meaning locals, the children go out to the cornfield where one of the corn cult members, Micah, has been possessed by a demon sent by He Who Walks Behind The Rows, the demonic entity the cult worships. Caught in the middle are reporter John Garret and his son Danny, who have a troubled relationship. John is in town working on a story about the children. He runs into two of his former coworkers, Bobby and Mac, who are leaving town and are soon killed by He Who Walks Behind The Rows. John begins a relationship with bed and breakfast owner Angela. Danny spends most of his time with a local, orphan girl, Lacey. Micah and the other children murder a local woman, Ruby Burke by dropping her house on her. Then they kill another member of the town by using a type of voodoo doll causing him to bleed to death. John begins to ask the town doctor questions about what is going on, but the doctor acts suspiciously and asks John to leave. The doctor is later stabbed to death by the children. Micah and the children then kill Mrs. Burke's sister, but it appears as if she was simply hit by a car. John teams up with Frank Red Bear, a professor at a nearby University to try and figure out what is going on. They discover that the residents of the town are planning to sell spoiled corn from the previous year's harvest along with the new crop. The spoiled corn has a toxin growing on it which they believe is the source of the children's delusions. The town Sheriff captures them, ties them up, and tries to kill them with a corn harvester, but they escape. The Sheriff and the rest of the town attend a meeting, but the children lock them inside and set the building on fire killing all of them. The children kidnap Angela and Lacey and bring them out into the cornfield. Danny agrees to join the children and Micah orders him to sacrifice Lacey. Danny hesitates, then John and Frank arrive driving the harvester. One of the children shoots Frank with an arrow and he is apparently killed. Danny and John free Lacey and Angela and attempt to escape, but they are eventually captured. Micah begins to harness the power of He Who Walks Behind The Rows. Then, Frank, who is still alive, starts up the harvester before he finally dies. Micah's robe gets caught in it, and calls for Danny to help. Danny hesitates but doesn't leave. Then, Micah's face transforms into the demon that possessed him. The demon then leaves him, making Micah himself again. Danny runs in to help him but it was too late, Micah was pulled in by the harvester and was shredded to bits. The rest of the children scatter, and Danny, Angela, Lacey, and John leave the clearing. Later, John and Danny reconcile and then they, Lacey, and Angela burn Frank's body and give him a funeral before they all drive off together away from Nebraska. ==Deaths== *Bobby Knite - Killed during twister when neck was cut with corn leaf. *Wayde McKenzie - Impaled through chest with corn stalk during twister. *Mrs. Burke - Crushed by house foundation. *David Simpson - Nose, Ears and Eyes bleed profusely via Voodoo magic. *Dr. Appleby - Stabbed to death with syringes, scalpels and finally a knife. *Mrs. West - Hit by truck, flies through a window. *At least a dozen after the children burn the church during a meeting. Including: : Sheriff Blaine, Mary Simpson, Reverend Hollings *Mordechai - Impaled with spear. *Frank Redbear - Shot by arrow before Mordechai's death, but recovers enough to re-start harvester. *Demon - Cast out of Micah as he struggles. *Micah - Finally killed after being drawn into harvester. ==Cast== *[[Ryan Bollman]] as Micah: The leader of the new corn group, successor of Isaac from the first film, who is possessed by a demonic spirit. *[[Paul Scherrer (actor)|Paul Scherrer]] as Danny Garret *[[Terence Knox]] as John Garret: Danny's father, reporter for the ''Worldly Inquirer''. *[[Christie Clark]] as Lacey Hellerstat: A local orphaned girl whom Danny has a crush on. *Marty Terry as Mrs. Ruby Burke *[[Sean Bridgers]] as Jedediah ==Production== Film production began at the end of spring 1992, and shooting began in summer 1992 in [[Liberty, North Carolina]]. Most of the cast were locals, including the children. The scene involving an elderly woman flying through a store window after her wheelchair becomes controlled by Micah was filmed in downtown Ramseur, North Carolina. The scene where Micah and the children of the corn burn the town elders was filmed in a home at the corner of Asheboro St. and Luther Ave. in Liberty. The home was burned for the film and a vacant lot remains where the house once stood. The production crew used a local parsonage at the corner of Fayetteville and Raleigh Sts. in Liberty as its headquarters during shooting. [[Brian Yuzna]]'s son Xeno appears as one of the children of the corn. In the DVD commentary, director David F. Price said during the shoot there was a local Christian group who held a few (low-key) protests during filming, and he received a dead rodent on his door step as a warning. As a result, the production constructed their own church for a few scenes in the film. Despite this, no actual incidents occurred. False, they used the Chatham Meeting house at the Snow Camp Outdoor Theatre. Also in the DVD commentary, Price said the ending involving Red Bear painting a stone was added at the last minute. Originally, it involved John Garrett making a phone call to his tabloid at a phone booth by the side of the road near the cornfield, only to have it swallowed into the earth by He Who Walks Behind The Rows, killing him. This was scrapped due to budget constraints. According to the original draft of the script, the film was going to be called "Children of the Corn 2: Deadly Harvest". ==Release== The film was originally only released on VHS in North America. In the UK, a PAL DVD was released but is time-compressed. On April 12th 2011, a Region 1 DVD was released by Echo Bridge Home Entertainment. ==Alternate Versions== U.S. print - 94 minutes
U.K. - Canada print - 89 minutes (Deleting a scene in which Micah becomes evil, which incorporates some CGI effects. This version also changes the opening credits music.) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0106557}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|children_of_the_corn_ii_the_final_sacrifice}} {{The Children of the Corn Series}} {{Media based on Stephen King works}} [[Category:1992 films]] [[Category:1992 horror films]] [[Category:Children of the Corn films]] [[Category:Sequel films]] [[Category:Supernatural horror films]] [[Category:Religious horror films]] [[Category:Films about religion]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films set in Nebraska]] [[Category:Films shot in North Carolina]] [[Category:Dimension Films films]]

{{Infobox settlement | name = Frasunek | settlement_type = Village | total_type =   | image_skyline = | image_caption = | image_flag = | image_shield = | image_map = | coordinates_region = PL | subdivision_type = [[Countries of the world|Country]] | subdivision_name = {{flag icon|Poland}} [[Poland]] | subdivision_type1 = [[Voivodeships of Poland|Voivodeship]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Greater Poland Voivodeship|Greater Poland]] | subdivision_type2 = [[Powiat|County]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Gostyń County|Gostyń]] | subdivision_type3 = [[Gmina]] | subdivision_name3 = [[Gmina Borek Wielkopolski|Borek Wielkopolski]] | latd = 51 | latm = 57 | lats = 41 | latNS = N | longd = 17 | longm = 11 | longs = 38 | longEW = E | pushpin_map = Poland | pushpin_label_position = right | elevation_m = | population_total = | website = }} '''Frasunek''' {{IPAc-pl|f|r|a|'|s|u|n|e|k}} is a [[village]] in the administrative district of [[Gmina Borek Wielkopolski]], within [[Gostyń County]], [[Greater Poland Voivodeship]], in west-central Poland.{{cite web |url=http://www.stat.gov.pl/broker/access/prefile/listPreFiles.jspa |title=Central Statistical Office (GUS) - TERYT (National Register of Territorial Land Apportionment Journal) |date=2008-06-01 |language=Polish}} It lies approximately {{convert|7|km|mi|0}} north-west of [[Borek Wielkopolski]], {{convert|16|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} north-east of [[Gostyń]], and {{convert|53|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} south of the regional capital [[Poznań]]. ==References== {{reflist}}

{{Taxobox | name = Anomura | fossil_range = {{fossil range|Norian|Recent}} | image = Dardanus megistos2.jpg | image_caption = The [[hermit crab]] ''[[Dardanus megistos]]'' | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Arthropod]]a | subphylum = [[Crustacean|Crustacea]] | classis = [[Malacostraca]] | ordo = [[Decapoda]] | subordo = [[Pleocyemata]] | infraordo = '''Anomura''' | infraordo_authority = [[William Sharp Macleay|Macleay]], 1838 | subdivision_ranks = Superfamilies | subdivision = *[[Aegloidea]] *[[Chirostyloidea]] *† [[Eocarcinoidea]] *[[Galatheoidea]] *[[Hippoidea]] *[[Lithodoidea]] *[[Lomisoidea]] *[[Paguroidea]] }} '''Anomura''' (sometimes '''[[Anomala]]''') is a group of [[Decapoda|decapod]] [[crustacean]]s, including [[hermit crab]]s and others. Although the names of many anomurans includes the word ''crab'', all true [[crab]]s are in the sister group to the Anomura, the [[Crab|Brachyura]] (the two groups together form the [[clade]] [[Meiura]]).{{cite journal |author=Gerhard Scholtz & Stefan Richter |year=1995 |title=Phylogenetic systematics of the reptantian Decapoda (Crustacea, Malacostraca) |journal=[[Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society]] |volume=113 |issue=3 |pages=289–328 |url=http://arthroinfo.org/pdfs/826/826.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.1995.tb00936.x}} ==Description== The name Anomura derives from an old classification in which [[Reptantia|reptant]] decapods were divided into Macrura (long-tailed), Brachyura (short-tailed) and Anomura (differently-tailed). The alternative name Anomala reflects the unusual variety of forms in this group; whereas all crabs share some obvious similarities, the various groups of anomurans are quite dissimilar.{{cite book |author=Gary Poore |year=2004 |title=Marine Decapod Crustacea of Southern Australia: a Guide to Identification |publisher=[[CSIRO Publishing]] |isbn=978-0-643-09925-8 |chapter=Anomura – hermit crabs, porcelain crabs and squat lobsters |pages=215–287 |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=TptuZCY3OU0C&pg=PA215}} The group has been moulded by several instances of [[carcinisation]] – the development of a crab-like body form.{{cite book |editor=Joel W. Martin, Keith A. Crandall & Darryl L. Felder |year=2009 |title=Decapod Crustacean Phylogenetics |volume=18 |series=Crustacean issues |publisher=[[CRC Press]] |isbn=978-1-4200-9258-5 |author=Shane T. Ahyong, Kareen E. Schnabel & Elizabeth W. Maas |chapter=Anomuran phylogeny: new insights from molecular data |pages=399–414 |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Bxs6SgSW2kQC&pg=PA399 |doi=10.1201/9781420092592-c20 |isbn=978-1-4200-9258-5}} Thus, the [[king crab]]s (Lithodidae), [[porcelain crab]]s (Porcellanidae) and [[hairy stone crab]] (Lomisidae) are all separate instances of carcinisation. As decapods (meaning ''ten-legged''), anomurans have ten [[pereiopod]]s, but the last pair of these is reduced in size, and often hidden inside the gill chamber (under the [[carapace]]) to be used for cleaning the gills. Since this arrangement is very rare in [[Crab|true crabs]] (for example, the small family [[Hexapodidae]]),{{cite journal |title=Differentiation of the fossil Hexapodidae Miers, 1886 (Decapoda: Brachyura) from similar forms |author=Carrie E. Schweitzer & Rodney M. Feldmann |journal=[[Journal of Paleontology]] |volume=75 |issue=2 |year=2001 |pages=330–345 |url=http://decapoda.nhm.org/pdfs/10789/10789.pdf|doi=10.1666/0022-3360(2001)075<0330:DOTFHM>2.0.CO;2}} a "crab" with only eight visible pereiopods is generally an anomuran. There is wide acceptance from [[morphology (biology)|morphological]] and [[molecular phylogenetics|molecular]] data that Anomura and [[Brachyura]] (true crabs) are [[sister taxa]], together making up the [[clade]] Meiura. ==Classification== The infraorder Anomura is divided into nine superfamilies:{{cite journal |journal = [[Raffles Bulletin of Zoology]] |year=2009 |volume = Suppl. 21 |pages=1–109 |title = A classification of living and fossil genera of decapod crustaceans |author=Sammy De Grave, N. Dean Pentcheff, Shane T. Ahyong ''et al.'' |url=http://rmbr.nus.edu.sg/rbz/biblio/s21/s21rbz1-109.pdf}}{{cite journal |author=Jérôme Chablais, Rodney M. Feldmann & Carrie E. Schweitzer |year=2011 |title=A new Triassic decapod, ''Platykotta akaina'', from the Arabian shelf of the northern United Arab Emirates: earliest occurrence of the Anomura |journal=[[Paläontologische Zeitschrift]] |volume=85 |pages=93–102 |doi=10.1007/s12542-010-0080-y |url=http://decapoda.nhm.org/pdfs/31744/31744.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}}{{cite journal |author=K. E. Schnabel, S. T. Ahyong & E. W. Maas |year=2011 |title=Galatheoidea are not monophyletic – molecular and morphological phylogeny of the squat lobsters (Decapoda: Anomura) with recognition of a new superfamily |journal=[[Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution]] |volume=58 |issue=2 |pages=157–168 |doi=10.1016/j.ympev.2010.11.011 |pmid=21095236}} {| class="wikitable" ! Superfamily !! Members !! Families !! Photo |- | '''[[Aegloidea]]''' || ''[[Aegla]]'' || [[Aeglidae]] || |- | '''[[Chirostyloidea]]''' || [[squat lobster]]s || [[Chirostylidae]]

([[Coenobitidae]]) |} The oldest [[fossil]] attributed to Anomura is ''[[Platykotta]]'', from the [[Norian]]–[[Rhaetian]] of the [[United Arab Emirates]]. ==References== {{reflist|32em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Crustaceans|Arthropods}} *{{commons category-inline}} *{{wikispecies-inline}} [[Category:Anomura| ]] [[Category:Decapods]] [[gl:Anomuros]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox Company | name = Rock River Arms Inc | logo = [[File:Rock River Arms logo.png|250px]] | type = [[Privately-held company|Private]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1996 | founder = Mark and Chuck Larson | defunct = | location_city = [[Colona, Illinois]] | location_country = [[United States|U.S]] | location = | locations = | area_served = [[United States|U.S]] | key_people = | industry = [[Manufacturing]] | products = [[Firearms]] | services = | market cap = | revenue = $22 Million<ref>http://www.indeed.com/cmp/Rock-River-Arms-Inc</ref> | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 50<ref>http://www.indeed.com/cmp/Rock-River-Arms-Inc</ref> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = http://www.rockriverarms.com/ | footnotes = | intl = }}
'''Rock River Arms''', Incorporated is a manufacturing company based in [[Colona, Illinois]] that manufacturers parts and accessories for [[AR-15]]/[[M16 rifle|M16]] type [[rifle]]s, as well as complete firearms.
==Law enforcement use== In December 2003, after outperforming 10 other manufacturers in rifle abuse tests, Rock River Arms was awarded a contract with the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] for a minimum of 5,000 LAR-15 rifles to be purchased over five years.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Petty |first=Charles |month=October |year=2004 |title=And Then There Was One: Feds Select New Fighting Rifle, Rock River's DEA Carbine |journal=Guns Magazine |pages=56–74 |url=http://www.rockriverarms.com/images/pdfs/gm_oct04.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=December 29, 2012}}</ref> As a result of Rock River Arms winning the DEA contract, other federal agencies, including the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] and [[United States Marshals]], have also obtained Rock River Arms weapons under piggyback contracts.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Oldham |first=Scott |month=January |year=2006 |title=Rock River Arms Entry Tactical |journal=Law and Order |url=http://www.hendonpub.com/resources/article_archive/results/details?id=4138 |accessdate=December 29, 2012}}</ref>
==Company history== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2011}} Rock River Arms is owned and operated by brothers Mark and Chuck Larson. Between 1981 and 1991 the Larsons worked at [[Springfield Armory, Inc.]], where Mark was the head armorer. From Springfield Armory, the Larsons went into partnership with Les Baer to form [[Les Baer Custom]] and build custom 1911 pistols. Parting ways with Les Baer in 1993, the Larsons began to build AR-15 type rifles for Eagle Arms in [[Coal Valley, Illinois]]. At around the same time, they began their own venture, Tolerance Plus (the name was later changed to Rock River Arms), producing custom 1911 pistols. The Larson brothers severed their connection with Eagle Arms in 1997 when that firm moved to [[Geneseo, Illinois]]. At the same time, Rock River Arms began to build AR-15 style rifles. For a time, Rock River Arms produced [[M1911]] pattern pistols in addition to rifles, however eventually they dropped that line and now focus their production exclusively on AR-15 pattern rifles.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.rockriverarms.com Official site]
[[Category:Firearms manufacturers in the United States]]
[[Category:Quad Cities]] [[Category:Companies based in Henry County, Illinois]]

revision.text:
[[File:Mahogany email screenshot.png|thumb|Mahogany on Windows Vista]] '''Mahogany''' is an [[open source]] cross-platform [[email]] and news client. It is available for X11/Unix and MS Win32 platforms, supporting a wide range of protocols and standards, including [[Simple Mail Transfer Protocol|SMTP]], [[Post Office Protocol|POP3]], [[Internet Message Access Protocol|IMAP]], [[Network News Transfer Protocol|NNTP]] (including [[Transport Layer Security|SSL]] support for all of them) and full [[MIME]] support. The current official release version is 0.67 (published in August 2006).<ref>[http://mahogany.sourceforge.net/status.html Development Status]</ref>
Mahogany is developed by The Mahogany Development Team (Founding members Karsten Ballüder and Vadim Zeitlin). It is licensed under a special Mahogany ''Artistic License'' similar to the Perl Artistic License<ref>[http://www.linux-magazin.de/heft_abo/ausgaben/2002/04/wat_mutt_dat_mutt Article on Linux-Magazin.de]</ref> but the developers also allow licensing the program under [[GNU General Public License|GNU GPL]] license.<ref>[http://mahogany.sourceforge.net/copyright.html Copyright]</ref>
The program features an optional embedded Python interpreter. Python scripts have full access to all internal Mahogany data structures and objects and can be used to extend Mahogany.
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://mahogany.sourceforge.net/index.html Mahogany site at sourceforge] * [http://www.linuxplanet.com/linuxplanet/reports/1978/4/ Article on linuxplanet.com] * [http://www.softpedia.com/get/Internet/E-mail/E-mail-Clients/Mahogany-Mail.shtml Download and short description at softpedia]
{{Email clients}}

{{Taxobox | name = Orange Clinid | regnum = [[Animalia]] | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Actinopterygii]] | ordo = [[Perciformes]] | familia = [[Clinidae]] | genus = '''Ericentrus''' | genus_authority = Gill, 1893 | species = '''''E. rubrus ''''' | binomial = ''Ericentrus rubrus '' | binomial_authority = ([[Frederick Wollaston Hutton|Hutton]], 1872) }}
The '''orange clinid''', ''Ericentrus rubrus'', is a [[clinid|weedfish]] of the genus ''[[Ericentrus]]'', found around [[New Zealand]] in rock pools and from low water to depths of about 15 m, in [[reef]] areas. It is the only member of its genus.
==References== * {{ITIS |id=638488 |taxon=Ericentrus rubrus |accessdate=11 March 2006}} * {{FishBase species | genus = Ericentrus | species = rubrus | month = January | year = 2006}} * Tony Ayling & Geoffrey Cox, ''Collins Guide to the Sea Fishes of New Zealand'', (William Collins Publishers Ltd, Auckland, New Zealand 1982) ISBN 0-00-216987-8
[[Category:Clinidae]] [[Category:Endemic marine fish of New Zealand]]

revision.text:
{{YearInPakistanNav|2011|nocat=yes}}
Events in the year '''2011 in the [[Pakistan|Islamic Republic of Pakistan]]'''.
==Incumbents== * [[President of Pakistan|President]] - [[Asif Ali Zardari]] * [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] - [[Yousaf Raza Gillani]] * [[Commerce Minister of Pakistan|Commerce Minister]] - [[Ameen Faheem]] * [[Minister of Communications (Pakistan)|Minister of Communications]] - [[Arbab Alamgir Khan]] * [[Culture Minister of Pakistan|Culture Minister]] - [[Khawaja Saad Rafique]] * [[Defence Minister of Pakistan|Defence Minister]] - [[Ahmad Mukhtar]] * [[Minister of Defence Production]] - [[Rana Tanveer Hussain]] * [[Finance Minister of Pakistan|Finance Minister]] - [[Abdul Hafeez Shaikh]] * [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] - [[Hina Rabbani Khar]] * [[Interior Minister of Pakistan|Interior Minister]] - [[Rehman Malik]] * [[Minister for States and Frontier Regions]] - [[Najmuddin Khan]] * [[Minister for Water and Power]] - [[Raja Pervaiz Ashraf]]
==Events== ===January=== [[File:Salmaan Taseer October 29, 2009 Lahore.jpg|thumb|140px|right|Salmaan Taseer, governor of Punjab was shot in January.]] *January 3: The government enters into urgent talks with opposition parties after the [[Muttahida Quami Movement]] resigns from the coalition, depriving it of its majority.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12106769 Pakistan PM Gilani in crisis talks with opposition]</ref> *January 4: [[Salmaan Taseer]], the governor of [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], is shot by one of his bodyguards near his home. Taseer dies of his wounds soon afterwards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12111831 |title= Punjab Governor Salman Taseer Assassinated in Islamabad, Pakistan |publisher=[[BBC news]] |date=2011-01-04 |accessdate=2001-01-04}}</ref> His killer, [[Malik Mumtaz Qadri]], turns himself in and claims he killed the governor due to his opposition to the [[blasphemy law in Pakistan]].<ref name="India News">{{cite web|url=http://blog.indiavoice.info/2011/01/governor-assassinated-in-islamabad.html |title=Governor assassinated in Islamabad, Pakistan |publisher=IndiaVoice |date=2011-01-04 |accessdate=2011-01-04}}</ref> *January 13: a reporter of [[GEO News|Geo News]], [[Wali Khan Babar]] is shot by unknown political gunmen in Karachi as target killing once again gripped the city.<ref>http://www.hindustantimes.com/Geo-News-reporter-shot-dead-in-Karachi/Article1-650165.aspx</ref> *January 19: Massive earthquake of magnitude [[Moment magnitude scale|M<sub>w</sub>]] 7.2 [[2011 Pakistan earthquake|hits]] southwestern parts of the country including [[Karachi]], with tremours jolting as far as [[New Delhi]] and [[Dubai]].<ref>http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/recenteqsww/Quakes/us2011ggbx.php</ref> *January 24: Another earthquake of magnitude [[Moment magnitude scale|M<sub>w</sub>]] 6.3 jolts the upper parts of the country including [[Islamabad]].<ref>http://www.sify.com/news/6-3-magnitude-earthquake-hits-pakistan-news-international-lbylkgcihja.html</ref><ref>http://pakistanweatherportal.com/2011/12/31/2011-astonishing-weather-events-in-pakistan/</ref> *January 25: At least thirteen people are killed while 70 others injured in a suicide bomb explosion in a mourning procession of Hazrat Imam Hussain near its concluding point at Kerbala Gamay Shah at Bhat Gate in [[Lahore]].<ref>http://www.geo.tv/1-25-2011/77631.htm</ref> *January 25: A suicide bomber rammed his explosive-laden motorbike into a police van at Malir 15 area of [[Karachi]], killing at least three people while 5 people were injured.<ref>http://www.geo.tv/1-25-2011/77637.htm</ref> *January 27: A US diplomat, [[Raymond Davis (diplomat)|Raymond Davis]], kills two men on a motorbike in [[Lahore]] allegedly in self defence while a companion of the diplomat, who is also an American citizen, crushed to death a bike rider in a hit-and-run incident, following the shooting.<ref>http://tribune.com.pk/story/109868/american-kills-pakistani-in-self-defence-police/</ref>
===February=== ===March=== March 1: The Ministor for Minority Affairs, Shahbaz Bhatti, a Christian was assisinated in Islamabad
March 30: Pakistan plays Cricket World Cup semi-final with India.
March 30: Famous Comedian Liaquat Soldier dies.
===April=== * April 22: Internationally renowned Pakistani actor, [[Moin Akhtar]], dies at the age of 60 years in Karachi after suffering from a heart attack.
===May=== * May 2: [[Death of Osama Bin Laden]]: The [[US Navy Seals]] killed [[Osama bin Laden]] in the city of Abbotabad. * May 24: Hakim Ali Zardari, father of President [[Asif Ali Zardari]] died at the age of 81 years at a private ward in the [[Pakistan Institute of Medical Sciences]] Hospital in Islamabad.
===June=== * June 24 - The cell phone of Osama bin Laden's courier is reported to contain contacts with [[Harakat-ul-Mujahadeen]], suggesting potential ties to Pakistan's intelligence agencies
===July=== During the months of July and August 2011, a number of targeted killings in Karachi, Pakistan left hundreds of people dead. The attacks are part of an ongoing terrorist campaign of political, ethnic and religious violence that has gripped the city in its worst form in the recent years. By late August and September 2011 the security situation in Karachi has stabilized and target killings have largely stopped, though isolated incidents still occur.
===August=== ===September=== ===October=== ===November=== * November 22: [[Husain Haqqani]] resigned as [[Pakistan Ambassador to the United States]] following claims of his alleged affiliation with the [[Memogate (Pakistan)|Memogate controversy]]. * November 26: A [[2011 NATO attack in Pakistan|NATO attack]] on two Pakistani border checkposts in [[Salala, Pakistan|Salala]] in the Baizai subdivision of [[Mohmand Agency]] in [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas|FATA]] kill 24 soldiers of the [[Pakistan Army]].
==Sport== * The [[2011 Cricket World Cup]] will be held in [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]] and [[Bangladesh]].
==Deaths== {{Expand section|date=May 2011}} * 4 January - [[Salmaan Taseer]], 64, governor of Punjab, shot dead<ref name="India News"/> * 10 January - [[Naseerullah Babar]], 82, soldier and politician, Governor of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (1976–1977) and Interior Minister (1993–1996).<ref>http://www.dawn.com/2011/01/10/former-interior-minister-naseerullah-babar-dies.html</ref> * 13 January - [[Wali Khan Babar|Babar]], 28, journalist and reporter, shot dead. * 22 January - [[Aslam Khokhar]], 91, cricketer.<ref>http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/23012011/28/pakistan-039-s-oldest-test-cricketer-dies.html</ref> * 23 January - [[Colonel Imam]], who was kidnapped along with former ISI official [[Khalid Khawaja]], British journalist Asad Qureshi and his driver in the tribal belt on March 26 last year, died due to a heart attack in the custody of his captors.<ref>http://news.oneindia.in/2011/01/24/kidnappedex-isi-official-with-close-taliban-linkdies-aid0126.html</ref> (''body found on this date'') * 22 April - [[Moin Akhtar]], 60, acclaimed Pakistani actor. * 2 May - [[Usama bin Laden]], 54, Saudi terrorist.
==Holidays in Islamic Republic of Pakistan== Following are the holidays which are held every year in Pakistan.
{|class="wikitable" ! style="background: #99CC99;" | Date ! style="background: #99CC99;" | English Name ! style="background: #99CC99;" | Local Name ! style="background: #99CC99;" | Remarks |- | February 5 | Kashmir Day | يوم کشمیر Yom-e-Kashmir |'''Kashmir Day''' has been observed on 5 February each year since 1990 as a day of protest against [[India]]n control of part of [[Kashmir]].<ref>{{cite news |title= Pakistan to observe Kashmir Solidarity Day today |url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/02/05/stories/2007020503731300.htm |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=2007-02-05 |accessdate=2008-02-05 }}</ref> It is a national holiday in [[Pakistan]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Kashmir Day being observed today |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/updates.asp?id=36715 |work=[[The News International]] |date=2008-02-05 |accessdate=2008-02-05 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> |- | March 23 | Pakistan Day | یوم پاکستان Yom-e-Pakistan | Commemorates the passing of the [[Lahore Resolution]], when a separate nation for the Muslims of The [[British Indian Empire]] was demanded. |- | May 1 | [[Labor Day|Labor day]] ([[May Day]]) | یوم مزدور
Yom-e-Mazdoor | [[Labor Day|Labor day]] in Pakistan |- | August 14 | Independence Day | یوم استقلال
Yom-e-Istiqlal | Commemorates Pakistan's independence from the [[United Kingdom]] on August 14, 1947 |- | November 9 | Birthday of [[Muhammad Iqbal]] | یوم اقبال Yom-e-Iqbal | Birthday of [[List of national poets|national poet]] [[Muhammad Iqbal]] |- | December 25 | Birthday of Quaid-e-Azam [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] | یوم ولادت قائداعظم Yom-e-Viladat-e-Quaid-e-Azam | Birthday of Quaid-e-Azam [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] founder/father of Pakistan |- !colspan="4"|Dates following the [[lunar calendar|Lunar]] [[Islamic calendar]] |- | [[Dhul Hijja]] 10 & 11 | [[Eid ul-Adha]] | عید الاضحٰی | Commemorates the end of [[Haj]]. The sacrifice offered on this day commemorates [[Abraham]]'s willingness to sacrifice his son, occurs on the 10th day of the month of [[Dhul Hijja]] |- | [[Shawwal]] 1 & 2 | [[Eid-ul-Fitr]] | عيد الفطر | Commemorates end of [[Ramadan]] (Ramazan). It occurs on the 1st and 2nd day of [[Shawwal]] |- | [[Rabi`-ul-Awwal]] 12 | [[Milad al-Nabi|Eid-e-Milad-un-Nabi]] | عيد ميلاد النبی | Birthday of Prophet [[Muhammad]]. It occurs on the 12th of [[Rabi'-ul-Awwal]] |- | [[Muharram]] 9 & 10 | [[Day of Ashura|Ashura]] | عاشوراء | Martyrdom of Hazrat Imam [[Hussain]]. It occurs on 9th and 10th day of [[Muharram]] |- | [[Rajab]] | [[Isra and Mi'raj|Shab-e-Miraj]] | شب معراج | It occurs on 27th of [[Rajab]] |}
===Provincial holidays=== These holidays were held in some provinces of Pakistan.
*5 January - All educational institutions, offices and banks remained closed in Punjab province to mourn the death of Salmaan Taseer. *19 January - The Sindh government had declared January 19 (Wednesday) a provincial holiday on account of the Urs of Shah Abdul Latif Bhitai.<ref>http://www.dawn.com/2011/01/19/holiday-in-sindh-today.html</ref> *25 January - The Sindh government declared a provincial holiday on the account of Chelum of Hazrat Imam Hussain.<ref>http://tribune.com.pk/story/108919/bomb-attacks-in-karachi-lahore-kill-11-officials/</ref>
==See also== *[[Terrorist incidents in Pakistan in 2011]] *[[2010 in Pakistan]] *[[2011|Other events of 2011]] *[[Timeline of Pakistani history]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Pakistan year nav}}
{{Asia topic|2011 in}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:2011 In Pakistan}} [[Category:2011 in Pakistan| ]]

revision.comment: r2.7.1) (Robot: Adding [[fr:Azzo X d'Este]]
revision.text:
'''Azzo X d'Este''' (1344–1415) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[condottiero]], a member of the [[House of Este]].
Born into a cadet branch of the family, he contested the seigniory of [[Ferrara]] to the young [[Niccolò III d'Este|Niccolò III]], an illegitimate son of marquess [[Alberto d'Este]] who was under the protection of [[Pope Benedict IX]] and [[Republic of Venice|Venice]]. After a failed attempt to poison him, Azzo created a ''compagnia'' of mercenaries, with the supports of some Este vassals. However, his invasions of the Ferrara territory was crushed by [[Azzo da Castello]], and he retired to the [[Modena|Modenese]].
With the help of [[Giovanni da Barbiano]] and an army of 8,000 men, in 1395 he tried again the capture of Ferrara, taking advantage of da Castello's death. But he was again heavily defeated at the [[Battle of Portomaggiore]] (April 16), this time by a Venetian army, and imprisoned. Later he was exiled to Candia ([[Crete]]).
He died in Venice in 1415.
==References== *{{cite book|last=Chiappini|first=Luciano|title=Gli Estensi. Mille anni di storia|location=Ferrara|year=2001}}

{{Infobox non-profit | name = Canadian Organization for Rare Disorders | image = [[Image:CORD ID v2 10-0128v2.jpg|160px|Canadian Organization for Rare Disorders logo]] | type = Non-Profit [[Charitable organization|Registered Charity]] | location = Suite 600, 151 Bloor St W, [[Toronto, Ontario]], M5S 1S4, [[CAN]] | key_people = President [[Durhane Wong-Rieger]]
Vice President Kirsten Harkins
Treasurer John Adams | area_served = [[Canada]] | focus = [[rare disorders]], [[rare diseases]], and [[advocacy]] | homepage = {{URL|raredisorders.ca}} }} The '''Canadian Organization for Rare Disorders''' ('''CORD''') is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[registered charity]] that is a network of organizations who represent people affected by [[rare diseases]]. CORD's purpose is to provide a strong common voice advocating for a healthcare system and health policy for those with rare disorders.{{Cite web| title=CORD Homepage | url=http://raredisorders.ca}}{{Cite web| url=http://www.istl.org/07-fall/internet1.html| title= Rare Disease Resource Page | accessdate=22 April 2010}} ==Overview== CORD represents the orphan disorders community in the development of Canadian [[Orphan Drug]] [[Health Policy|Policy]], including the proposed Expensive Drugs for Rare Disorders program within the National Pharmaceutical Strategy CORD is working to promote state-of-the-art Newborn Screening in all provinces and territories. CORD is working to ensure Canada's Clinical Trials Registry works effectively for those with rare disorders. CORD is committed to increasing access to genetic screening and genetic counseling for all rare disorders. Currently, [[Durhane Wong-Rieger]] is the President of CORD.{{Cite web| url=http://www.geneticalliance.org/organization/canadian-organization-rare-disorders | title=Genetic Alliance advocacy}}{{Cite web| title=About CORD | url=http://raredisorders.ca/aboutUs.html}} Their national offices are located in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], with an Alberta chapter located in [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]].{{Cite web| url=http://search.hipinfo.info/record/BTN4426 | title=Halton Community Service Database}} ==See also== *[[Rare diseases]] *[[National Organization for Rare Disorders]] American based organization *[[European Organization for Rare Diseases]] *[[Rare Disease Day]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.raredisorders.ca/ Official Website] *[http://www.facebook.com/RareDisorders CORD] Fan Page on [[Facebook]] {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Canadian Organization For Rare Disorders}} [[Category:Drug policy organizations]] [[Category:Charities based in Canada]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:Non-governmental organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:Patients' organizations]] [[Category:Rare diseases]]

{{Infobox company |company_name = Java Green |company_logo = [[Image:RADAGroup.svg|250px]] |company_type = [[private Company|Private]] |company_slogan = Think Bigger,Think Better. |location = [[Andheri]] - West, [[Mumbai]] | |founder = [[Anil Ambani]] |key_people = [[Anil Ambani]]
([[Chairman]]) |num_employees = |industry = Food |homepage = http://java-green.com }} '''Java Green''' is a café chain from [[Reliance Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group]] - [[India]]. Spread nationwide in [[Reliance World]] and many [[shopping mall]]s in important cities, where it serves [[coffee]] in many varieties (hot and cold). ==History== Javagreen was started in 2003 as a chain of In-Store Cafés within [[Reliance World]], to serve Reliance’s broadband and cellular customers. Post de-merger of the Reliance Group, Javagreen has expanded into other store – in - store locations outside Reliance. Today Javagreen is the largest chain of In-Store Cafes, with over 100 cafes operating within a host of retailers, food courts and corporate campuses. ==Products== [[File:Latte art.jpg|thumb|250px|Coffee]] [[Image:Irish Violet Crumble.jpg|thumb|right|A [[chocolate]] milkshake.]] [[Image:White hot chocolate.JPG|thumb|upright|White hot chocolate]] Javagreen products are made with exclusive recipes and a host of proprietary ingredients developed by their in-house team of chefs. Their exclusive coffee blend is sourced directly from [[Chikkamagaluru]], the place where the best Indian coffees are grown. The cold beverages are made from proprietary ingredients that give them a unique taste & texture. Javagreen has a wide choice of hot and cold beverages, coffees & non – coffees; Teas, Chocolate Drinks, Soups, Smoothies, Shakes, Granitas, Frappes & Mocktails. Their range of fresh sandwiches, paninis & burgers are made to order, customized just the way the customers want. ==Locations== Javagreen is now operational across 10 cities in India with a mix of store in store formats and independent outlets. It is currently open at over 90 locations in: * [[New Delhi]] * [[Mumbai]] * [[Kolkata]] * [[Chennai]] * [[Bangalore]] * [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] * [[Pune]] * [[Ahmedabad]] * [[Lucknow]] * [[Kochi]] * [[Nadiad]] Java Green is operational at various stores and locations such as: * '''Educational Institutions''' - [[DA-IICT]], [[IIM Bangalore]]. * '''Hospitals''' - KDA Hospital - [[Mumbai]], Fortis. * '''Corporate HQ''' - DAKC - [[Navi Mumbai]], IBM. * '''Telecom stores''' - Reliance Webwords. * '''Malls''' - Spencer's mall. ==See also== * [[List of fast food restaurant chains]] * [[Café Coffee Day]] * [[Haldiram's]] * [[Monginis]] * [[Nirula's]] ==External links== * [http://www.java-green.com Java Green official site] {{Reliance Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group}} [[Category:Food companies of India]]

{{cleanup|date=February 2011}} {{refimprove|date=January 2010}} The '''Non-Resident Violator Compact (NRVC)''' is an [[interstate compact]] used by 44 states in the [[United States]] to process traffic citations across state borders.
Motorists cited for violations in a state that is not a member of the NRVC must post bail before being allowed to proceed.
When a motorist is cited in another member state and chooses not to respond to the ticket (such as not paying it), the other state notifies the driver's home state and the home state will suspend the driver's license until the driver takes care of the matter in the other state.
There are certain offenses where the Non-Resident Violator Compact does not apply. Those offenses are registration, weight limit, and parking. Some states will not take action on offenses like vehicle equipment and vehicle inspection if their driver has ignored an out of state citation of those offenses. Out of state moving violations are the focus of the compact and there will be no differences in focus under the [[Driver License Agreement]].
==History==
The Non-Resident Violator Compact came into existence in the 1970s, originating from the northeastern states.
The Non-Resident Violator Compact is being superseded by the new Driver License Agreement (DLA) which also replaces the Driver License Compact. As planned by the DLC-NRVC Executive Board, when the Driver License Agreement is ratified by Non-Resident Violator Compact members, it will no longer be relevant.
==States that are members== * All states plus the [[District of Columbia]] are members except [[Michigan]], [[Wisconsin]], [[California]], [[Montana]], [[Oregon]], and [[Alaska]].<ref name="states">[http://www.aamva.org/uploadedFiles/MainSite/Content/DriverLicensingIdentification/DL_ID_Compacts/Compact%20Member%20Joinder%20Dates.pdf http://www.aamva.org/uploadedFiles/MainSite/Content/DriverLicensingIdentification/DL_ID_Compacts/Compact%20Member%20Joinder%20Dates.pdf]</ref>
==Notes== * Most states where a citation is issued will suspend your license in that state while you maintain the right to drive in your home state that is not a member of the NRVC * Most states will also issue a warrant for your arrest as well as sending the suspension request to your home state. * If you are traveling through NRVC member states, and you are licensed in one of the non-member states, it may be a good idea to carry enough cash to pay bond for any traffic violations you are stopped for and required to pay before leaving. * Being required to pay bond roadside is NOT a plea of guilt. You may appear in court on the date indicated on your citation, and if found not-guilty, should have the bond refunded.
<!-- ''Also see "http://www.aamva.org" American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators''. Also see "http://www.aamva.org/KnowledgeCenter/Driver/Compacts/" Driver License Compacts: Jurisdictional Agreements, which has links to the procedures documents. Note: The governing body for the NRVC is the DLC-NRVC Executive Board, made up of U.S. State and Canadian Provincial DMV officials elected by the State and Provincial representatives. AAMVA, as the secretariat for the DLC-NRVC Executive Board, provides administrative secretarial services to the Board. -->
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Traffic law}}
